title: NYPD Pushes Ban on Repeat Subway Sex Offenders
summary: Outlawing repeat sex offenders from mass transit is likely to face enforcement challenges. New York Police Department officials on Wednesday said they support banning repeat subway sex offenders from using the city's system, a proposal Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew Cuomo recently backed.

title: Humanitarian Disaster Grows in Southern Africa After Cyclone
summary: Resume Subscription. Southern Africa was scrambling on Wednesday to respond to a humanitarian disaster in the wake of Cyclone Idai, as the death toll rose and infrastructure connecting the poor region was destroyed, dealing a heavy economic blow and impeding aid delivery.

title: Bayer Shares Fall After Legal Setback on Roundup Weedkiller
summary: Chemicals and pharmaceuticals giant has warned the legal battle is just beginning as number of lawsuits is around 11,200. BERLIN-Shares of Bayer AG tumbled 9.6% Wednesday-the biggest single-day percentage decline in seven months-after the chemicals and pharmaceuticals giant faced another legal setback in its fight against accusations that its Roundup weedkiller causes cancer.

title: Yellow Taxi Drivers Press Albany to Rollback Congestion Pricing
summary: A caravan of cabbies asked lawmakers to use the money it raises to roll back a fee on taxis that took effect last month. As state lawmakers consider a broader system of congestion pricing for New York City, a caravan of cabbies came to the Capitol on Wednesday to ask them to use the money it raises to roll back a fee on taxis that took effect last month.

title: Fed Signals Rates Will Stay Steady Amid Growth Fears
summary: Eleven of 17 officials didn't think an increase would be needed at all this year-up from two in December. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve officials indicated Wednesday they are unlikely to raise interest rates this year and may be nearly finished with the series of increases they began more than three years ago now that U.S. economic growth is slowing.

title: The Internet and Evil
summary: The problem of live-streamed violence defies easy fixes.. Footage of last week's massacre in New Zealand, which the shooter streamed in real time via Facebook Live, quickly proliferated. The original 17-minute webcast was viewed fewer than 200 times and wasn't immediately reported, Facebook says. Some user finally flagged the video to Facebook 12 minutes later, but by then it had been copied to the internet's darker lairs.

title: Patience Is Now a Fed Virtue
summary: The central bankers now expect no rate increases in 2019.. If President Trump were gracious-don't laugh-he'd send a thank you note to Jerome Powell. The Federal Reserve Chairman all but admitted on Wednesday that he and the Fed were wrong in favoring tighter monetary policy three months ago and all but called off interest-rate increases through 2019.

title: Germany's NATO Backslide
summary: Berlin seems happy to validate Trump's spending criticism.. German politicians love to heap scorn on President Trump, but then they shouldn't try so hard to prove him right. Witness this week's Berlin backslide on military spending.

title: The Debt Crisis Is Coming Soon
summary: To avoid economic distress, the government has to reduce future entitlement spending.. The most dangerous domestic problem facing America's federal government is the rapid growth of its budget deficit and national debt.

title: Macron's Reversal of Fortune Is a Crisis of Empathy
summary: France's president feeds the perception of haughty arrogance that motivates the gilets jaunes.. France's gilets jaunes protests seemed to be losing steam, but they erupted again Saturday, a day after President Emmanuel Macron wrapped up his national grand débat-what an American politician might call a listening tour.

title: Miller Lite Brings the Bud Knight Back to Life (Sort of)
summary: Campaign for March Madness Picks Up Where Bud Light's Super Bowl Ads Ended. Miller Lite's latest ad assault on Bud Light picks up seconds after its larger rival's biggest Super Bowl ad ended, imagining what happens after the commercial stops shooting. No surprise: The actors, even the guy playing the Bud Knight, pick up cans of Miller Lite.

title: Health Care's Killer App: Life Insurance
summary: The industry could profit by helping policyholders pay for cancer treatments that prolong life.. Imagine a scenario in which a 57-year-old man with an individual health-insurance policy is diagnosed with cancer. As soon as the diagnosis is made, the incentives of the man and those of his health insurer diverge.

title: Levi Strauss Heads Back to Public Markets
summary: Denim maker is selling shares at $17 apiece for a valuation of roughly $6.6 billion. Levi Strauss & Co. is set to go public for the second time Thursday as the jeans maker jumps on an IPO wave being ridden most notably by big tech startups such as Lyft Inc. and Uber Technologies Inc.

title: Why New Yorkers Flee for Florida
summary: Our hearts go out to you for your sagging luxury real-estate market. But you did this to yourself.. A recent article in a Beltway publication warned about a potential recession and considered how it might affect President Trump's chances at re-election. The story began-no joke: "The luxury real estate market in Manhattan is sagging." It goes on to argue that softening in the real-estate market in high-tax Northeastern states is caused by the 2017 tax-reform law. Thus the claim is that because taxpayers can deduct only $10,000 in state and local taxes from their federal returns, America is heading for a recession.

title: Notable & Quotable: Math Won't Stop Us From Impeaching Kavanaugh
summary: 'If I waited for Republican approval before I tried something, I'd be shining shoes at Grand Central.'. From "The Time Has Come for Democrats to Impeach Brett Kavanaugh" by Elie Mystal, TheNation.com, March 20:

title: Parents Gone Wild
summary: College admissions offices thought they were doing good. They created dog-eat-dog.. The fantastic college-admissions scandal calls to mind one of the most famous sayings in American life: "We have met the enemy and he is us." Its wise author, the great cartoonist Walt Kelly (he created Pogo) would have gotten a kick out of explanations for the alleged fraud, which have become an exercise in turning away from the mirror and blaming someone or something else.

title: Robert Francis O'Rourke, Reloaded
summary: The Texan's campaign for president looks a lot like his failed Senate campaign.. Human nature being what it is, many candidates run for office the same way they did the last time. Take the 15th Democratic presidential candidate, former Rep. Robert Francis O'Rourke.

title: College Coaching Doesn't Hurt the Poor
summary: My clients' kids are competing with other privileged children.. The college cheating scandal has prompted criticism of wealthy students who can afford expert coaching, including from firms like mine. It's misguided. If you climb Mount Everest after receiving months of training, should folks dismiss your achievement because you had help?

title: 'White Shoe' Review: Lawyering Up the 20th Century
summary: The rise of the modern law ﬁrm paralleled the rise of the corporation. To be a robber baron was to need not a lawyer but an entire legal team.. For better or worse, lawyers have been with us ever since John Winthrop arrived at Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1630. But it was not until the final years of the 19th century that lawyers assumed a prominent place in American business and public life. They did so most notably in New York among graduates of Ivy League colleges, whose students were known for palling around in white buckskin shoes with red soles and heels. This transformation of the practice of law is the focus of John Oller's entertaining history, "White Shoe."

title: U.S. Dollar Falls After Fed Signals Longer Pause
summary: Slide follows central bank's signaling of a cautious approach to further tightening. The U.S. dollar fell Wednesday after the Federal Reserve signaled it is unlikely to raise interest rates this year.

title: Third Lawsuit Filed Over Medicaid Work Requirements
summary: New Hampshire residents are challenging the Trump administration's support of work requirements for Medicaid recipients, after suits filed in Arkansas and Kentucky. WASHINGTON-Several Medicaid enrollees in New Hampshire sued the Trump administration over the state's work requirements for program participants, marking the third such lawsuit and raising pressure on the administration to justify its support of the new rules.

title: Brazil Central Bank Leaves Selic Rate Unchanged at 6.5%
summary: Says economy still needs stimulative interest rates. BRASÍLIA-Brazil's central bank held its benchmark interest rate at its all-time low for the eighth consecutive meeting as financial markets await the outcome of the government's efforts to get a pension overhaul proposal through Congress.

title: Supreme Court Weighs Racial Bias in Jury Selection for Murder Case
summary: Prosecutor dismissed at least 41 of 43 potential African-American jurors without explanation at the trials. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court appeared set to throw out a murder conviction from Mississippi amid evidence of racial bias after dramatic arguments Wednesday that concluded with a rare question from Justice Clarence Thomas.

title: With Personal Connection to Crash, Ralph Nader Takes On Boeing
summary: The longtime activist, who lost a young relative in the Ethiopian Airlines crash, puts out a call for whistleblowers. Ralph Nader's latest and most unlikely anti-corporate campaign focuses on a crash site in Ethiopia.

title: Estée Lauder Revamps IT, Merging Beauty Business With Innovation
summary: Cosmetics company considers uses for artificial intelligence, data analytics and 3-D printing. Cosmetics industry mainstays like Estée Lauder Cos. are looking at ways new technology can help them stay competitive amid rivals that now include dozens of new beauty brands that are growing fast and appealing to younger crowds.

title: Amid College Admissions Bribery Scandal, USC Names New President
summary: Carol Folt, former head of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, will try to move University of Southern California past crises. One of the colleges in the alleged admissions cheating case, the University of Southern California, named as its new president Carol Folt, former head of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: Measure of U.S. Innovation Jumped in 2018
summary: Multifactor productivity grew 1% last year, the strongest gain since 2010. The iPhone, Amazon, and Uber have yet to deliver the kind of productivity boom that led to a burst of American prosperity in previous eras of technological advances. But new data suggest the latest technology boom is starting to give the economy a jolt.

title: U.S. Government-Bond Yields Tumble After Fed Restraint
summary: Yield on the benchmark 10-year note hits its lowest level in more than a year. U.S. government bonds rallied Wednesday, sending the 10-year Treasury yield tumbling to its lowest level in more than a year, after the Federal Reserve signaled it was unlikely to raise interest rates at all in 2019.

title: Houses of Worship Upgrade Security After Shootings
summary: Churches, mosques and synagogues seek to balance safety with desire to remain open and inviting. So far this year, 18 faith-based groups have reached out to security consultant Steve Padin for help developing safety plans, more than twice as many as in all of 2018.

summary: Food maker among those raising prices. General Mills Inc. boosted profit with higher prices, but sales volume slipped in the latest quarter for the maker of Cheerios cereal and Yoplait yogurt.

summary: Economy minister lays out plan to lawmakers that would set tougher retirement rules, save a net $2.8 billion over 10 years. summary: Nine West Holdings Inc. has been renamed Premier Brands Group Holdings LLC. Apparel and accessories company Nine West Holdings Inc. has exited bankruptcy proceedings and has been renamed Premier Brands Group Holdings LLC.

summary: An exhibition at the Rubin Museum of Art provides a much needed corrective to the prevailing tendency in the West to view Tibetan Buddhism and its adherents exclusively through the lens of spirituality and pacifism..

title: Stocks Decline After Fed Decision
summary: Stocks jumped after Fed statement, but have since given up gains. U.S. stocks and Treasury yields fell Wednesday after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged and a majority of officials signaled they might not raise them at all this year, raising fears about a slowdown in economic growth.

title: BlackRock Offers Its Lowest Ever Price for Index Mutual Fund
summary: Money manager's move is indication of pressure firms face to lower prices of their most common stock-and-bond investments. BlackRock Inc. is cutting the price big clients pay to invest in its largest equity index mutual fund, a bid by the giant money manager to close the gap with cheaper rivals.

title: Acting Defense Chief's Boeing Ties Scrutinized
summary: Outside complaint says Shanahan promoted former employer over competitors. title: What AI Is Still Far From Figuring Out
summary: Machines have gotten better at applying rules, but will they ever match humanity's ability to come up with new ideas?.

Top state lawmakers called for new efforts to change admissions for New York City's eight specialized high schools, after data this week showed less than 11% of black and Latino students were offered seats there for next fall.

title: China, Russia Stand to Gain From Kazakhstan's Smooth Transition
summary: New president aims to maintain nation's security ties to Moscow, economic links to Beijing. A smooth political transition after the unexpected resignation of Kazakhstan's longtime leader serves the interests of neighboring Russia and China, which have economic and security stakes in the region.

title: Trump Says Islamic State About to Lose Its Last Hold on Syrian Land
summary: 'A tiny spot that will be gone tonight,' president says. WASHINGTON-President Trump said the Islamic State extremist group would suffer its final territorial defeat by Wednesday evening, even as U.S.-backed fighters in Syria were still completing the battle against the militants.

title: Bernie Sanders and Venezuela
summary: The Vermont socialist tries to pretend he didn't encourage a brutal regime.. As. Sen. Bernie Sanders runs for President again, he keeps trying to persuade voters that his governing socialism would be the soft Scandinavian kind, not the hard Soviet kind. There's immediately a problem with his Scandinavian analogy, since the countries of that region have been running away from Sanders-style economics and in recent years have become champions of corporate tax rate-cutting. The larger problem is his ongoing commitment to an abusive regime.

title: A New Kind of Retiree Is Heading to the Mediterranean
summary: The region is seeing home buyers who are younger, richer and more active than those seeking post-career homes in the past. The Mediterranean's luxury enclaves have long attracted sun-hungry retirees, who traditionally wanted little more out of a home than a southern exposure and a glimpse of the sea. Now, a new wave of early and semi- retirees is upending the market from Venice to Spain.

title: Bayer Shareholders Face the Lawyers
summary: Bayer's stock plunge highlights the difficulty in handicapping what companies may owe in lawsuits. Investors are once again faced with a very modern investing problem: how to grapple with the power of U.S. civil courts.

title: Why Tinder Is the Long Island Iced Tea of Dating Apps
summary: To help you choose the digital matchmaker that's right for you, we asked: 'What kind of drink would each one be?'. WHILE I can't point to the single most important lesson that dating in New York has taught me, I now know that the first drink you or your companion chooses can make a statement. Whether it's a craft IPA or a piña colada, brown liquor drowning one big cube, or a few shots of Patrón, it sets a certain vibe, helping you write the story of an evening before your glasses clink.

title: Investors Watch for Clues on Fed's Patience on Rates
summary: Central bank to release new policy statement and updated economic projections. Federal Reserve officials are on track to leave interest rates unchanged at their two-day meeting ending Wednesday and could indicate they are comfortable holding them steady for a while.

title: Celebrity Jeweler Suspected in $2 Billion Fraud Arrested in London
summary: Nirav Modi built global jewelry empire, according to authorities, on web of illegal loans guaranteed by state-owned Punjab National Bank. LONDON-India's onetime jeweler to the stars, Nirav Modi, has been arrested in London and faces extradition to India to face allegations that he defrauded lenders of nearly $2 billion, in what Indian authorities say could be their country's biggest-ever banking scam.

title: Pompeo's Visit to Israel Seen as Election Boost to Netanyahu
summary: Secretary of State's visit comes ahead of polls in April in which the prime minister is seeking fifth term. TEL AVIV-U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo arrived in Israel on Wednesday to discuss threats the country faces from Iran and its allies, a visit that buttresses Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's campaign message as he seeks to win a fifth term in April 9 elections.

title: Our Underperforming Immigration System
summary: I think Neeraj Kaushal is confused about the difference between legal immigration and illegal immigration. Most citizens are for the first, but every citizen should be against the second.. Regarding Tunku Varadarajan's "The Weekend Interview with Neeraj Kaushal: America's Great Immigration System" (March 9): How can Ms. Kaushal claim it is "comic[al]" to say thousands of illegal immigrants breaching our southern border is a real emergency. How can someone with her impressive credentials not see the danger and detrimental effect of thousands of unchecked people illegally entering our country? How can people who don't respect our basic laws, who use our schools, our hospitals and bring disease and gangs into our country serve our economy or our country "quite well"? Why would some immigrants spend months to years becoming American citizens when they can just walk across our border? Ms. Kaushal ends by saying we are lucky in our country that not everybody has the same "vision on immigration." I think she is confused about the difference between legal immigration and illegal immigration. Most citizens are for the first, but every citizen should be against the second.

title: The Pentagon Must Spend Its Money Better, Not Just More of It
summary: The Pentagon already has enough resources to keep America secure. What it needs is smarter policies, not more money.. Regarding your editorial "Trump's Pentagon Budget War" (March 12): Too many in Washington believe that the bigger the Pentagon budget is, the safer the U.S. will be. This frame of mind provides lawmakers with an excuse to continue their addiction to lavish spending.

title: Democrats Really Do Own Education Reform
summary: Democrats are the predominant party in the vast majority of districts with the largest numbers and concentrations of charter-school students.. Regarding Jay P. Greene and Frederick M. Hess's "Democrats Have Taken Over Education Reform" (op-ed, March 8): The current administration's education agenda is harmful to our nation's most vulnerable students. President Trump has sought to undo the very protections and innovations that are helping millions of students receive a better education.

title: 'The Dream Is You: Vanessa Rubin Sings Tadd Dameron' Review: A Tribute to the Romanticist of the Bebop Movement
summary: Vocalist Vanessa Rubin honors Tadd Dameron with an album that highlights his compositional genius.. The great composer and arranger Tadd Dameron (1917-1965) wrote "If You Could See Me Now," one of Sarah Vaughan's signature songs, but until now the rest of his formidable catalog of music, which includes jazz standards like "Lady Bird" and "Good Bait," has rarely featured vocals. Vanessa Rubin, a vocalist who like Dameron is a Cleveland native, has long been a fan of his compositions. Now she's released a recording more than a decade in the making, "The Dream Is You: Vanessa Rubin Sings Tadd Dameron" (Nibur).

title: What Makes Bob Newhart Laugh?
summary: Still hitting the stage at 89, the comedy legend on noodling with jokes, forgiving Toyota and the enduring genius of 'Dr. Strangelove'. But the car drives so damn well, I've kind of forgiven them for it. I'll mostly drive to all the same places, like a computer store-a Best Buy or Staples or something-to see if there's anything new out there that I haven't heard of yet.

title: Yes, the U.S. Could Be Drawn Into Yet Another Big War
summary: The tragedy of the Iraq invasion has done little to alter the factors that have led American leaders and the public into unwise military adventures. Sixteen years ago this week, the George W. Bush administration sent U.S. forces crashing into Iraq without a real plan for what to do after defeating Saddam Hussein. It is easy to forget that moment's fervent convictions about the Iraqi dictator's supposed weapons of mass destruction and links to al Qaeda-and the calamity into which Iraq soon descended. It all seems to belong to another era. The debate today is more about how we got out of Iraq than how we got in.

title: 'Us' Star Winston Duke, a Towering Presence Whose Profile Is Still Growing

title: Google Fined $1.7 Billion in EU Over Limiting Rivals' Ads
summary: Decision is last among three sets of formal charges that European Commission has so far filed against the tech giant. BRUSSELS-Alphabet Inc.'s Google was penalized yet again by European antitrust regulators, this time with a €1.49 billion ($1.7 billion) fine for limiting how some websites could display ads sold by its rivals.

title: Gas-Tax Hike: A Rare Big Idea With Bipartisan Backing
summary: U.S. Chamber of Commerce advocates raising federal gasoline tax to help fix the country's crumbling transportation network. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce isn't exactly a hotbed of pro-tax sentiment. So when the chamber advocates for a tax increase, it's worth sitting up to take notice.

title: The Life and Death of Grimes
summary: As she readies the release of her new album, Grimes-who now goes by 'c'-opens up about her influences and relationships, and why she's decided to kill off her musical persona. Claire Elise Boucher hates all her names, especially her middle name, but even the name she invented a decade ago, the name she performs music under and is famous as: Grimes. "I think I'll kill 'Grimes' soon," she says. "It will be a public execution followed by-by something else. I shouldn't say yet." Meanwhile, for now, she asks to be called c (italicized and lowercase). Just like, as she's fond of pointing out, the shorthand for the speed of light in a vacuum, or 186,282 miles per second.

title: Detroit Downloads Tesla's Software Strategy
summary: Industry moves toward wireless updates to repair problems and deliver extras. Auto makers have outfitted new cars with a lot of technology, effectively turning them into computers on wheels. Their next challenge: refreshing the software remotely, so people don't have to drive to the dealership for updates.

title: Investors Fret Over Fed Rate Path Amid Mixed Data
summary: Hiring unexpectedly slowed sharply in February; consumer spending has remained robust. The Federal Reserve is widely expected to keep interest rates steady at the conclusion of Wednesday's meeting, but analysts are worried that some investors are over-anticipating a dovish policy stance from the central bank.

title: Is $430 Million All It's Cracked Up to Be?
summary: Mike Trout sets a record for a professional sport deal. The Fabergé eggs are on him.. I'll say what we are all thinking about Mike Trout's big, fat, brand-new $430 million baseball contract:

title: U.S. Companies Cross the Atlantic for Bond Love
summary: Companies are issuing bonds at a healthy clip again-and an active corner of the market is so-called 'reverse Yankee' bonds. Companies have returned in force to the bond market following one of the weakest stretches in years. One corner of the market-U.S. companies raising money in Europe-is on a particularly strong run.

title: Pfizer Adds to Big Pharma's Gene-Therapy Deal Streak
summary: Pharmaceutical giants are betting on gene therapies to cure intractable diseases. Pfizer Inc. has agreed to pay as much as €560 million ($636 million) for the rights to gene therapies under development at French company Vivet Therapeutics, as it seeks to build its pipeline in this cutting-edge treatment.

title: Ethiopia Fast-Tracks Boeing 737 MAX Crash Probe
summary: Preliminary accident report into crashed Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302 could be published next week. ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia-Air-accident investigators in Ethiopia are taking the unusual step of fast-tracking their probe into last week's crash of a Boeing 737 MAX airliner amid global safety concerns around the jet and could issue a preliminary report on the accident as early as next week, the head of Ethiopia's civil-aviation authority said Wednesday.

title: Carlos Ghosn's Case Likely to Be Put on Fast Track, Lawyer Says
summary: Trial of former Nissan chairman over alleged financial misconduct could begin this fall. TOKYO-The trial of former Nissan Motor Co. Chairman Carlos Ghosn could begin as soon as the fall, his lawyer said, suggesting the court doesn't want the case to take years, as they often do in Japan.

title: Loans Get Cheaper for Some
summary: Data suggests financial institutions are jostling for customers by offering lower rates, particularly to those with good credit scores. WASHINGTON-Borrowing costs for some U.S. consumers have trended lower in recent months, as lenders have adapted to the Federal Reserve's message that it is likely to hold off on raising interest rates for the foreseeable future.

title: Copper Prices Get Shanghaied
summary: Prices of the metal, which have lost steam recently, bear more than a casual resemblance to trends in China's rates and stock market.. Students of global markets may have noticed that when it's sunny in Shanghai, copper prices tend to gleam brighter, too.

title: Investors Are Still Too Sunny on Ray-Ban
summary: A row over who will lead the sunglasses brand's newly merged parent threatens cost savings. The optics are poor in Ray Ban's leadership row. Shareholders have no other way to bet on the promising global eyewear market, but are still underplaying the drama.

title: Collaboration Market Racing Ahead
summary: A broad change in workplace culture is helping to drive growth in enterprise collaboration tools like Microsoft's Teams. Microsoft Corp. is leveraging a strong position in cloud computing and enterprise software to drive growth for Teams, its two-year-old enterprise collaboration tool, IT industry analysts and researchers say.

title: Disney Closes $71.3 Billion Deal for 21st Century Fox Assets
summary: Deal for $71.3 billion merges 'Simpsons' and 'Star Wars,' and it builds a bigger competitor to Netflix. Walt Disney Co. closed its $71.3 billion acquisition of the major entertainment assets of 21st Century Fox , the companies said, combining some of Hollywood's best-known studios, characters and franchises as media companies look to get bigger to better compete in a world where shows and movies are increasingly streamed.

title: How She Got a Job Watching Baseball
summary: The Oakland A's scouting coordinator shares how a determined approach put her in position to succeed in a male-dominated field. Women have had a long history with professional baseball, from leagues like the one depicted in the 1992 film "A League of Their Own" to scattered positions in ownership.

title: Jury Finds Bayer's Roundup Weedkiller Caused Man's Cancer
summary: Second phase of the trial will weigh Monsanto's liability. SAN FRANCISCO-A jury found that a man developed cancer from exposure to Roundup weedkiller he used in his yard, in the second case to go to trial over the alleged harms of the popular Bayer AG product.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: New Zealand Pushes Back Against Erdogan's Threats in Wake of Massacre
summary: Turkish leader upset New Zealand and Australia by linking Christchurch attack and 1915 World War I battle. New Zealand plans to confront Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan after he said last week's mosque attack was part of a broader plot against his country and threatened to send New Zealanders and Australians home in coffins.

title: Next on House Democrats' Target List: Documents From Giuliani, Tillerson, Cohn
summary: Democrats consider sending a second wave of document requests to Giuliani, Tillerson, Cohen's lawyer, others. WASHINGTON-The House Judiciary Committee is eyeing additional document requests to associates of President Trump, including Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani and a former lawyer for Michael Cohen who last year sought a pardon on his client's behalf, according to a person familiar with the committee's plans.

title: Court Upholds Chicago Officer's Sentence in Teen's Killing
summary: Prison time of less than seven years for second-degree murder stands in teen's 2014 shooting. CHICAGO-The Illinois Supreme Court on Tuesday let stand a prison sentence of less than seven years for a white Chicago police officer convicted of killing black teenager Laquan McDonald that many criticized as far too lenient.

title: As Funerals Begin, Families of New Zealand Attack Victims Wait in Anguish
summary: First two funerals completed by midafternoon Wednesday in Christchurch. When Sameer Khan's grandmother was killed in Afghanistan after the American invasion, his family swiftly cleaned her body and buried her within a day on the outskirts of Kabul.

title: New Zealand Mosque Shooter Was En Route to Third Target, Police Say
summary: Investigators now say the accused gunman was apprehended within 21 minutes, down from initial estimate of 36 minutes. CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand-Accused killer Brenton Tarrant was on his way to a third target when he was apprehended by police roughly 21 minutes after they were alerted to the shooting at the Al Noor mosque, investigators believe.

title: U.S. to Stop Detaining Some Migrant Families at Border
summary: Trump administration moves to relieve overcrowding in facilities as immigration surges. The Trump administration plans to start pulling back on a controversial plank of U.S. immigration policy in a busy border region, saying Tuesday it will stop sending some migrant families who illegally cross the border in Texas' Rio Grande Valley to jail.

title: Biden Tells Supporters He Plans 2020 Bid
summary: Former vice president asks for help in lining up contributions from major donors so he can quickly raise several million dollars. Former Vice President Joe Biden told at least a half-dozen supporters Tuesday he intends to run for president and asked for their help in lining up contributions from major donors so he can quickly raise several million dollars, a person familiar with the matter said.

title: Three Executives to Oversee AT&T's Warner Bros. Studio Following Departure of CEO Tsujihara
summary: Warner chief stepped down after an investigation into a relationship he had with an actress several years ago. Three senior Warner Bros. executives will oversee operations at the studio in the wake of former Chief Executive Kevin Tsujihara's resignation after an investigation into a past relationship with an actress, WarnerMedia head John Stankey said in a memo to staff Tuesday.
